name: Hjálparfoss - The Helping Waterfall
description: Hjálparfoss, whose name translates to "Helping Falls" or "Helper Falls," is a uniquely beautiful twin waterfall in South Iceland where two rivers—the Fossá and the Þjórsá (Iceland's longest river)—converge and cascade side by side at approximately 45-degree angles to each other before merging into a single flow. This unusual Y-shaped waterfall configuration creates a distinctive visual composition where two separate white curtains of water tumble simultaneously over dark volcanic rock ledges into a shared pool below, framed by the columnar basalt and ancient lava formations from which they emerge. The waterfall's height is modest at approximately 10-12 meters, but what it lacks in vertical drama it more than compensates for in scenic charm and geological interest. Hjálparfoss sits within the Þjórsárdalur valley surrounded by the massive Þjórsárhraun lava field, which was created by an eruption in the Veiðivötn fissure system approximately 8,700 years ago and represents the largest known lava flow on Earth since the end of the last Ice Age. The lava at Hjálparfoss has weathered and eroded over millennia into fascinating formations including hexagonal basalt columns, caves, and unusual rock shapes that visitors can explore on short walks around the waterfall area. The name "Helping Falls" derives from the historical importance of this river confluence point: shepherds driving sheep between highland summer pastures and lowland winter pastures would gather at this spot where the rivers were shallow enough to ford safely, making the location a crucial "helper" for livestock movement across the challenging Icelandic terrain. A small stone building near the waterfall—historically used as a shelter for travelers and shepherds—has been preserved and adds to the site's pastoral charm. One of Hjálparfoss's greatest advantages for visitors is its accessibility: unlike many of Iceland's spectacular waterfalls which require 4x4 vehicles or lengthy hikes, Hjálparfoss is reached via paved roads (Route 1 to Route 30 to Route 32) with only a short gravel section at the end, making it suitable for regular passenger cars in good weather conditions. The drive from Reykjavík takes approximately 1.5-2 hours covering about 120 kilometers. A small parking area provides direct access to viewpoints, and visitors can walk to multiple vantage points including close approaches to the base of the falls and higher viewpoints that show the full Y-configuration of the convergent waterfalls. The surrounding lava landscape is fascinating to explore, with moss-covered rocks, small caves, and the constant roar of water creating an immersive natural experience. Nearby attractions in the Þjórsárdalur valley include Háifoss waterfall (one of Iceland's tallest), the historic Stöng Viking-age farm reconstruction, and views of Hekla volcano, making Hjálparfoss an excellent addition to a South Iceland highlands itinerary.
